comment_data.body:
just did a quick rundown with claude and found the cause

```
In commit 2d4ece4a (8 days ago) there was a change:

  What Changed:
  -- Added to vtsls.lua, eslint.lua, biome.lua, ts_ls.lua, tsgo.lua:

  -- exclude deno
  if vim.fs.root(bufnr, { 'deno.json', 'deno.jsonc', 'deno.lock' }) then
    return
  end

  The Bug:
  The root_dir function uses a new API where it must call on_dir(project_root) instead of returning a value. The early return
  statement exits the function without calling on_dir(), which prevents the LSP server from starting.


  Possible explanations:
  1. There might be deno files in a parent directory that vim.fs.root() is finding
```

after checking, i did indeed have a random deno.lock in my `$HOME` folder which was not allowing any of those lsp to start (actually, ts_ls.lua was working).

Deleting it fixed the problem, but this file has been there for a while.

is this intended behavior or a regression introduced possibly in 2d4ece4a with #4130?

Thanks for narrowing down the issue!

> i did indeed have a random deno.lock in my `$HOME` folder

That is a more general problem, and only accidentally "caused" by https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/4130 . It does not imply that https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/4130 is wrong.

I have been thinking about how to deal with the usually-unwanted situation where HOME dir is treated as a "root dir". It is a core problem, not a nvim-lspconfig problem.

Tracked here:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36654

title: [Vtsls,Biome,Eslint] lsp not starting
